The partial shutdown of the federal government is now entering month two, and federal prisons are desperately trying to hang on amid a shortage of staff and resources, according to several reports.CNN spoke with prison employees†and a union president who said the shutdown means workers are logging double shifts and are even asking maintenance and medical staff to fill in for corrections officers.At the Metropolitan Correction Center in New York, which houses some 800 detainees, several inmates initiated a hunger strike last week in response to the cancelation of family visits due to low staff numbers, The New York Times reported. The Bureau of Prisons told CNN there was no hunger strike, a claim that was contradicted by Eric Young, the American Federation of Government Employeesí president of the Council of Prison Locals.†Young wrote an open letter†to senators last Tuesday, urging lawmakers to act to end the shutdown.ìWe work in an already dangerous and stressful environment, where going to work distracted or fatigued can lead to serious injury or death,î he said, adding that employees are wondering how to pay bills, as many ìare being required to work mandatory overtime, and do so without pay.îìIt is a recipe for disaster because a distraction could cost you your life.îOn Friday, Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) met with federal employees, including two Bureau of Prisons staffers from the stateís Fort Dix prison, and called attention to those struggling to make ends meet without a paycheck.The day before, Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.) also met with local prison workers, highlighting the roughly 3,000 in his state who, he said, ìhave been risking their lives each day as they continue to work without pay.î

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) accused House Democrats of trying to ìswing electionsî with a major piece of legislation designed to clean up voting and campaign finance and strengthen government ethics.McConnell described the so-called For the People Act as a ìpower grabî and a ìnaked attempt to change the rules of American politics to benefit one partyî in a Thursday op-ed for The Washington Post.The top Republican criticized Democrats for introducing the bill, also known as HR1, while the longest-ever partial government shutdown continues.ìHouse Democrats wonít come to the table and negotiate to reopen the government, but theyíve been hard at work angling for more control over what you can say about them and how they get reelected,î McConnell wrote.Later Thursday, McConnell blocked legislation aimed at reopening most of the federal government, except the Department of Homeland Security, according to The Hill.An op-ed from @senatemajldr Mitch McConnell:Call H.R. 1 what it is: The Democrat Politician Protection Act. https://t.co/saz0P110es pic.twitter.com/1C8rwTysq1The act, the first major bill House Democrats have introduced to the 116th Congress, contains a package of reforms that aim to make voting more accessible, force President Donald Trump (and future presidential candidates) to release their tax returns and take power away from big political donors by incentivizing smaller donations and by requiring super PACs to make their private donors public. The bill also aims to make Election Day a paid holiday for federal workers, which McConnell dismissed as a ìgenerous new benefitî for ìfederal bureaucrats.î In theory, that proposal would encourage private businesses to also make Election Day a holiday, allowing more people to get to the polls. McConnell also suggested that making private donors public was an attack on free speech.ìApparently the Democrats define ëdemocracyí as giving Washington a clearer view of whom to intimidate and leaving citizens more vulnerable to public harassment over private views,î McConnell wrote.The Republican also took issue with the billís ban on removing people from voter rolls for not voting in a previous election, as well as a ban on voter caging, a practice in which election officials send non-forwardable mail to addresses on the voter rolls, then remove anyone whose mail is returned to sender. McConnell pointed to a mistake made in California that led to 23,000 voters being registered incorrectly, with errors including wrong party preferences.However, linking that part of the bill to the mishap in California is misleading, according to HuffPostís voting rights reporter Sam Levine. ìIt was an issue with software, and the head of the DMV resigned,î Levine noted on Twitter. ìFor context, there are over 19.6 million registered voters in CA. Automatic registration added 727,924 people to the rolls since launch in April.îìThe law congress is proposing authorizes the states to set up their own systems for registering voters. People have to be given the chance to opt out,î Levine tweeted. The law would prevent states from aggressively purging the voter rolls by removing people if they donít vote and donít respond to a single mailer from the state, he said. ìProponents of the change argue that this practice removes eligible voters from the rolls.îMitch McConnell writes an op-ed criticizing HR 1, leaving his critiques for voting measures for four sentences at the bottom of the piece. His characterization is misleading. pic.twitter.com/h2jPrW40brIt was really bad that 23,000 people got on the rolls in California. It was an issue with software and the head of the DMV resigned. For context, there are over 19.6 million registered voters in CA. Automatic registration added 727,924 people to the rolls since launch in April.The law congress is proposing authorizes the states to set up their own systems for registering voters. People have to be given the chance to opt outThe law would prevent states from aggressively purging roles by removing people if they don't vote and don't respond to a single mailer from the state. Proponents of the change argue that this practice removes eligible voters from the rolls.On ballot harvesting: Sen. McConnell's party is arguing in North Carolina that alleged ballot harvesting didn't make a difference in the election. HR 1 requires early voting and pays for postage on absentee ballotsDemocrats brushed off McConnellís criticism of their bill.Rep. John Sarbanes (D-Md.), who introduced the bill earlier this month, tweeted Thursday night, ìIf [McConnell] is against it, then #HR1 must be a pretty good idea.îIf @senatemajldr is against it, then #HR1 must be a pretty good idea. #ForThePeopleRead McConnellís full op-ed here.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Though the federal government shutdown has come to an end, the date of President Donald Trumpís State of the Union speech remains a question mark.Speaking with reporters Friday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) made clear that the presidentís address hadnít been scheduled yet. It was initially scheduled to be delivered in the House chambers this Tuesday, but it fell victim to the shutdown.ìWhat Iíd said to the president is when the government is open, we will discuss a mutually agreeable date, and Iíll look forward to doing that and welcoming the president to the House of Representatives for the State of the Union when we agree on that mutually agreeable date,î Pelosi said.SOTU on Tuesday? Pelosi doesn't seem to think so: pic.twitter.com/ERpaCFrPM0Earlier this month, Pelosi revoked Trumpís invitation to appear before the House and deliver his remarks, deciding it wasnít the right time given the shutdown and its impact on unpaid security details.In a resulting tit-for-tat, Trump vowed to ignore Pelosiís wishes, Pelosi reiterated that she had shelved the invitation, then Trump angrily recognized the cancellation.Though Trump has signed a bill to get the government up and running, Pelosi wants to see the actual reopening occur before putting Trumpís speech on the calendar.The speaker and the president have faced off over his demands for more than $5 billion to build a border wall, with Pelosi teaming up with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) to oppose money for the barrier.†Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Several Democratic lawmakers announced plans on Monday to take federal workers who were furloughed during the partial government shutdown as their guests to President Donald Trumpís State of the Union address this week.ìItís time to send a message to President Trump and Senate Republicans: federal and contract workers are the backbone of our economy and their livelihoods should never be used as pawns in Republican political games,î Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) said in a statement.She said she invited Sajid Shahriar, a labor leader and an employee of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to join her for the address.Shahriar was one of roughly 380,000 federal workers furloughed during the shutdown, Warrenís office said. Those furloughed workers, along with 420,000 federal employees who were required to report to work during the shutdown, went 35 days without pay while Trump sparred with congressional Democrats over $5.7 billion in funding for a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border.†ìIím humbled and honored to share that I will be representing federal workers at the State of the Union as the guest of U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren,î Shahriar said in a statement.Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) said Monday that her guest for the State of the Union would be Trisha Pesiri-Dybvik, an air traffic control specialist who was furloughed during the shutdown.Pesiri-Dybvikís husband is an air traffic controller and was required to work without pay during the lapse in appropriations. The familyís home burned down in the 2017 Thomas fire.ìSince the tragic loss of their home, Trisha, Jed, and their three children have worked diligently to bounce back and reestablish a sense of normalcy in their lives, even amidst an unnecessary government shutdown that caused both of them to miss their paychecks for over a month,î Harris said in a statement.Rep. Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.) said Monday that she had invited Frank Lagunas, an employee of the Environmental Protection Agency, to attend Trumpís address. Lagunas works as a project manager for the EPAís Superfund division and was furloughed during the recent shutdown.ìI want to show President Trump how his hostage-taking of American workers has a continuing impact on the lives of every day citizens, especially those who are dedicated to the public good,î Schakowsky said in a release.Trump is set to deliver the State of the Union address on Tuesday night.House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) had earlier asked him to postpone the speech, originally planned for Jan. 29, until the shutdown was over.†When he initially refused to do so, she said she would not take the necessary steps to allow the address to proceed.†After Trump†announced a plan†on Jan. 25 to reopen the government for three weeks, Pelosi invited him to deliver the address on Feb. 5.If he doesnít get funding for his border wall by the end of the negotiation period on Feb. 15, Trump has said he is prepared to shut down the government again.Pesiri-Dybvik said in a statement that federal workers feel added stress because of ìthe looming uncertainty of another potential shutdown.îIn his announcement about reopening the government, Trump promised that federal employees who had been affected by the shutdown would get backpay ìvery quickly or as soon as possible.îBut workers like Lila Johnson,†a general cleaning services contractor at the Department of Agriculture, probably wonít see any lost wages. Many government contractors <U+2015> from food workers and janitors to security services and computer software developers <U+2015> were also furloughed or received stop-work orders during the shutdown. But unlike federal employees, they likely wonít receive backpay.Johnson will join Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) at the SOTU address, his office said.ìLow- and middle-wage federal contract workers who were locked out of their jobs during the shutdown have been stuck with mounting bills and no back pay,î Van Hollen said in a statement.Van Hollen and Sen. Tina Smith (D-Minn.) last month introduced the Fair Compensation for Low-Wage Contractor Employees Act to ensure government contractors are paid for lost wages due to the shutdown.ìI appreciate the Senator inviting me to join him for the State of the Union to highlight the need for federal service contractors to be treated fairly,î Johnson said. ìI know he is fighting for us, and Iím grateful for his efforts.îThis story has been updated with Rep. Jan Schakowskyís guest.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Hereís how.

Theyíve become crazy. The message doesnít even make sense anymore. Itís almost an anti-American message.îWhile the left overall has not advocated for totally open borders or sought the bankruptcy of all Americans as Eric contends, the exaggeration of liberal platforms has made them easier for conservatives to discount.Meanwhile potential democratic nominees for the presidency are either considering or actively throwing their hats into the ring ahead of 2020, including Sens. Kamala Harris (Calif.), Elizabeth Warren (Mass.), Kirsten Gilibrand (N.Y.) and Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (Hawaii).Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Hereís how.

President Donald Trump is offering a three-year extension to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, but one of its recipients is urging Democrats to reject the deal.†He is placing the proposal on the table as a bargaining chip to end the partial federal government shutdown, which was caused in part by his demands for more than $5 billion to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border. But Belen Sisa, a Dreamer who spoke with CNN on Sunday, said it was the wrong solution.ìI think they should absolutely not take this deal, and the reason why is because right now DACA is still in place,î she told the networkís Ana Cabrera. ìCourts are upholding and protecting the program that President Obama passed, and we will continue to fight, but we will not do it at the expense of others.î"They should absolutely not take this deal."-- Dreamer @belensisaw on President Trump's offer to Democrats to end the government shutdown, which includes extending temporary protections for DACA recipients. pic.twitter.com/sHJhxa59nbAs Sisa noted, there has been no end yet to the legal fight to keep the 2012 Obama-era initiative in place, and so far, it remains intact.On Saturday, contrary to his sometimes xenophobic remarks, Trump delivered a unifying statement in reaction to a naturalization ceremony that he participated in that day.The speech described U.S. citizenship as having ìno distinctions or race or class or gender or background,î adding, ìwe are all equalî and ìone team.îTo Sisa, the words were meaningless.ìIf anything, this sounds completely hypocritical,î she said in response. ìHis actions are not matching his speech. Theyíre not matching anything that he said.îContinuing to bash the remarks, Sisa contended that Trump ìhas been running this country and even campaigned on us not being equal.îìHow could he turn around and slap us in the face?îThough Trump announced the proposal only Saturday, it has already been turned down by many Democrats ó including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) ó who said itís a one-sided push from the president to get $5.7 billion for his wall.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Ahead of news that the partial government shutdown had ended, Michael Bloomberg made a round of speeches mocking President Donald Trump as a competence-free ìpretend CEO,î comparing his tenure to a scary movie.Speaking at a Friday gathering of the Democratic Business Council of Northern Virginia, the former New York City mayor flayed the president for triggering chaos in Washington. Bloomberg vowed to make sure the president doesnít serve another term.ìThe presidency is not an entry-level job,î Bloomberg said. ìThere is just too much at stake.îìAnd the longer we have a pretend CEO who is recklessly running this country, the worse itís going to be for our economy and for our security. This is really dangerous.îHe then panned Trumpís White House with a film reference, suggesting there wasnít much separating the president from a villain.†ìItís like the government version of a bad horror movie, but instead of Freddy Krueger and the ëNightmare on Elm Street,í weíve got Donald Trump and the ëNightmare at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.íîFollowing his appearance at the business councilís event, Bloomberg made a stop at the U.S. Conference of Mayors in Washington, D.C., where he echoed his previous sentiments and laid out a strong condemnation of the shutdown.ìThis is about competence and the lack of it we are seeing in the White House,î he said. ìThe government shutdown is a complete failure of executive leadership, and itís one of the worst cases of incompetent management I have ever seen.îBloomberg, who has flirted with the idea of a presidential run, has still made no mention of his plans for 2020. When Senate Republicans released a draft bill†on Monday night with a wall funding-for-Dreamer protections deal, it quickly became clear that this wasnít the compromise to end the partial government shutdown that President Donald Trump had touted.The bill would gut the asylum system. It would make it easier to deport Central American children who arrive in the U.S. without their parents. It would expand Immigration and Customs Enforcementís detention and deportation budget by more than 20 percent.Perhaps most galling, it didnít even offer a better deal for Dreamers than the status quo, even though concessions on that issue were hyped as the compromise that would bring Democrats to the shutdown negotiating table. Under the draft bill,†recipients of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals protection could apply for a new program with stricter requirements that would offer similar deportation protection and work authorization, but that would permanently expire three years later.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) is set to bring this legislation up for a pointless vote on Thursday. The measure is all but certain to fail in the Senate and would be impossible to pass in the House.ìItís beyond poisoned pills <U+2015> they didnít even try,î Ur Jaddou, former chief counsel for Citizenship and Immigration Services, told HuffPost. ìThereís not even an iota of effort to come up with a compromise. Itís shocking.îWhen Trump unilaterally canceled DACA in September 2017, many observers assumed that he did so in order to give himself leverage to demand concessions†from Democrats related to immigration and border security <U+2015> like funding for a U.S.-Mexico wall, for example. Holding the security of 700,000 Dreamers hostage in order to fulfill his controversial campaign promise does have a certain logic to it.Events since his DACA strike have undermined Trumpís position somewhat. Multiple federal judges have temporarily blocked the programís cancellation and so far the Supreme Court has refused to fast-track its consideration of the injunctions that allow Dreamers to keep renewing their DACA protections <U+2015> for now.Trump still has tremendous leverage when it comes to DACA. Having been created through executive action, the program can be reversed by hostile presidents who follow the law.†And the program is currently stuck in legal limbo. Supporters of immigration reform, including Dreamers themselves, have long demanded a permanent solution, ideally with a pathway to citizenship.But Trump is not a Machiavellian strategist, using the twin weapons of deception and terror to achieve his ends. Heís merely an obstructionist self-promoter for whom disaster is its own reward, as long as itís on brand.Thatís why he threatened to veto <U+2015> and thereby doomed <U+2015> a bill†last year that would have made DACA permanent and set out a pathway to citizenship in exchange for $25 billion in wall money. And thatís why the draft bill unveiled Monday night made an offer that the Democrats couldnít possibly accept.ìThis is so far away from a good faith effort,î said Philip Wolgin, the managing director for immigration policy at the Center for American Progress. ìItís nowhere near ëLetís make a trade: DACA for the wall.íîSome observers casting about for signs that a rational mind in the White House might honestly be cooking up a solution to the problem of Trump refusing to sign a shutdown-ending bill without some wall money are now watching Jared Kushner. Trumpís son-in-law and adviser is trying to ìfigure out what bigger immigration reform looks like,î†including a possible ìpath to green cardsî for DACA recipients, according to an Axios report†on Wednesday.The phrase ìpath to green cardsî is another way of saying the more commonly heard ìpathway to citizenship,î albeit in a form that sounds less objectionable to hardline immigration restrictionists. Without a joint session, the president wouldnít be able to come onto the House floor to deliver his address.The president can technically enter the House chamber at any time, but as McClatchy reporter Emma Dumain noted, there might not be anyone else there, let alone C-SPAN broadcasting or even lights.Trump could technically face censure or removal from the chamber if he decided to enter House and begin his address without express permission from Pelosi, according to House rules. But as Pacific Standard outlined, thereís no precedent for a president doing so against the wishes of the House speaker.Pelosi,†who became House speaker this month after Democrats won control of the chamber, extended the traditional invitation to Trump†on Jan. 3. An evangelical church in Alabama handed out†$16,500 in grocery store gift cards to local federal workers and contractors struggling to make ends meet during the ongoing†partial government shutdown.The First Baptist Church of Huntsvilleís grand gesture on Thursday was part of a wider community-led effort to help furloughed workers in Alabamaís third-largest city, which is home to NASAís Marshall Space Flight Center and the Armyís Redstone Arsenal.First Baptistís senior pastor, Travis Collins, told HuffPost that the church emptied out its disaster relief fund <U+2015> which held $14,000 <U+2015> and collected an additional†$2,500 from its members to help fund the charity effort. The church purchased over 300 Publix gift cards from a local grocery store in $50 increments.†Within 30 minutes of opening the churchís doors on Thursday, all the gift cards were gone, Collins said.The pastor said he was moved by how many people had lined up that morning at his church to receive the cards.†ìThat was probably the most impactful moment,î he said. ìJust seeing that many people who have done the right thing, prepared for a job, got a job, worked at a job and for circumstances beyond their control, now theyíre in need of temporary assistance.î†Now in its fifth week, the partial government shutdown was triggered by disagreements between President Donald Trump, who is demanding more than $5 billion for a U.S.-Mexico border wall, and Democrats in Congress, who donít want to allocate any new money for it. The shutdown has affected 800,000 federal workers, about 420,000 of whom must still report to work, even without being paid.†In Alabama,†nearly 40,000 federal employees have been affected by the shutdown,†The Washington Post reports.Collins said that many members of his congregation are NASA or Redstone Arsenal employees. First Baptist is a conservative evangelical congregation aligned with the†Cooperative Baptist Fellowship and the Southern Baptist Convention.Below, Collins invites furloughed workers to attend a charity event at First Baptist Church of Huntsville.The pastor emphasized that his church is just one of many local organizations helping federal workers during the partial shutdown. He said the idea for Thursdayís event came from workers at NASAís Marshall Space Flight Center who wanted to create an opportunity for local charities and businesses to connect with furloughed workers. As one of Huntsvilleís largest churches, First Baptist had the space to accommodate such an event.†Eighteen community organizations set up information booths in the church, including the local food bank, the Alabama Department of Labor and banks offering low-interest loans, CNN reports. At least 700 people attended the event, Collins said.†First Baptistís ministry staff are meeting on Monday to discuss future partnerships with community organizations helping furloughed workers, he said.ìOur only regret is that we didnít designate more money,î Collins said. ìWe had no idea how big the response would be.îAcross the country, other religious communities have pitched in to help federal employees affected by the shutdown. A church in Chula Vista, California, started a food bank for furloughed employees, and churches in Dallas†and Atlanta and a synagogue in Chattanooga, Tennessee, offered gift cards. Muslim youth groups across the country organized volunteers to clean up national parks amid the shutdown.Collins said he sees First Baptistís donation as a ìnatural responseî to the crisis.ìItís kind of corny and all, but I think Jesus would be there giving away grocery cards or heíd be right there volunteering with any organization that is helping,î Collins said. ìSo itís not like weíre going above and beyond the call of duty.îDo you have information you want to share with HuffPost? The agency has been taking job applications on its website and plans a high-profile hiring push later this year.†The Census Bureau was able to continue preparing for the count during the government shutdown with $1.1 billion from 2018 that could only be used for the 2020 census, The Washington Post reported.Pay for the jobs varies by location. In Washington state, for example, hourly pay ranges from $14.50 to $18, according to The Columbian.The†Census Bureau jobs site†says applicants should meet the following criteria:The bureau notes that most of the jobs require access to a computer with internet and email, and a car and valid driverís license, unless the employee is near public transit.The majority of the positions are for jobs that will last for a few weeks. WASHINGTON <U+2015> One week into the three-week negotiating period before another possible government shutdown, President Donald Trump yet again demanded that lawmakers give him billions of dollars for a wall along the Mexican border.He also hinted that he would declare a national emergency if they did not.All while simultaneously claiming <U+2015>†falsely†<U+2015> that he has already built and is currently building ìa lotî of the wall.So went the latest twists Thursday in Trumpís continuing efforts to get U.S. taxpayers to provide the money for a ìgreat, greatî wall that he promised hundreds of times during his campaign he would force Mexico to pay for.ìThere is no wall going up,î said Rick Tyler, a Republican consultant who worked for Texas Sen. Ted Cruzís campaign during the 2016 presidential primaries. ìSo the only thing to conclude is that Trump is building a fake wall with fake pesos to stop fake caravans to prevent a fake border crisis for which he will declare another fake victory.îThe president triggered a 35-day government shutdown just before Christmas over the refusal by the then wholly Republican-led Congress to appropriate billions of taxpayer dollars for his signature campaign promise.A week ago, he signed the exact short-term spending deal <U+2015> with no wall money <U+2015> that he said he would not sign in December. On Thursday, he said he did so to help the 800,000 federal workers who already had missed a month of pay. He claimed, without evidence, that ìmanyî of them had wanted him to continue the shutdown to get wall money.ìBut I didnít want to do it because people were getting hurt,î Trump told reporters following an Oval Office photo opportunity.He added that the shutdown had great value because it focused attention on the wall and illegal immigration. ìIf I didnít do the shutdown, people wouldnít know, people wouldnít understand the subject,î the president said. ìNow they understand the subject. They understand what a humanitarian crisis it is.îTrump has taken to blaming former Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan for failing to get him funds for a wall during Trumpís first two years in the White House, when his own party controlled both chambers of Congress. ìI was very disappointed in Paul because the wall was so desperately needed,î he told the conservative website Daily Caller.But one former Trump campaign official said the president failed to take advantage of his first-year power when he had it. ìThe fact of the matter was itís his fault for not getting it in his first two years, when he had control of Congress. He can blame Paul Ryan all he wants,î the official said on condition of anonymity.Now, with the House under the control of Democratic Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Trump is facing vocal opposition to his wall rather than just passive resistance. ìThereís not going to be any wall money in the legislation,î Pelosi said Thursday, but allowed that she is open to some new barriers in some areas as well as money for better technical monitoring. ìThatís part of the negotiation.îTrump made illegal immigration and caravans of asylum-seekers heading to the border the centerpiece of his midterm election message last year. In speech after speech, he told audiences at his rallies and those watching at home that the migrants would bring crime and drugs and that Pelosi wanted ìopen bordersî and would welcome those people in.Despite his efforts <U+2015> and in some congressional districts, because of them <U+2015> Democrats picked up 40 seats in the House. Meanwhile, Republicans, although they had the most favorable Senate election map in decades, picked up only two seats in that chamber.As a Dec. 21 government funding deadline approached, Trump resumed talking about caravans and immigrants coming to commit crimes <U+2015> including one particularly lurid but apparently apocryphal description of kidnapped women being bound and gagged with duct tape as theyíre smuggled across the border.On Thursday, Trump told reporters that he doubted the House and Senate conference committee negotiators working on a new Department of Homeland Security funding bill would include money for his wall. He acknowledged that he might yet declare a ìnational emergency,î which he believes would let him transfer money from other executive agency accounts to build the wall.ìIím waiting till Feb. 15,î Trump said, referring to the next shutdown deadline. ìOn Feb. 15, the committee will come back. And if they donít have a wall, I donít even want to waste my time reading what they have.îMedia reports from when Trump previously threatened to declare an emergency noted that he was thinking of raiding billions of dollars from the Defense Departmentís Army Corps of Engineers budget to repair hurricane damage in places like Puerto Rico and Houston.ìThose are not great ideas,î said Michael Steel, once a top aide to then GOP House Speaker John Boehner.Steel added that since Democrats seem willing to agree to money for some new physical barriers, he did not fully understand talk about an emergency or another shutdown.ìThe president can say, ëThis is a wall.í The Democrats can say, ëNo, it isnít.í And everyone lives to fight another day,î Steel said. ìIt shouldnít be hard.îDo you have information you want to share with HuffPost? As the partial government shutdown entered its fifth week, President Donald Trump proposed a trade Saturday: Give me $5.7 billion in border wall money, and Iíll agree to protecting refugees and immigrants who came here as children for three years.Most Democrats dismissed the offer immediately Saturday. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) shot down the deal to extend protections for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals immigration proposal as a ìnon-starter.îIn a statement issued before Trumpís speech, Pelosi said the idea was a ìcompilation of several previously rejected initiatives, each of which is unacceptable and in total, do not represent a good faith effort to restore certainty to peopleís lives.îTrump, meanwhile, falsely presented the proposal as something he had worked out with Democrats.He said he thought many Democrats would show their ìenthusiastic support,î and he said his solution was a ìcompassionate response to the ongoing tragedy on our southern border.îBut the offer, which Trump made from the White Houseís Diplomatic Reception Room, seemed less like a serious effort to end the shutdown and more like his normal blame-shifting.In response to the speech, Democratic Rep. Bennie Thompson (D-Miss.) said on MSNBC that Trumpís deal was a ìpipe dream,î and that Democrats would dismiss this speech as a publicity stunt.While the offer certainly doesnít seem to be a solution to the shutdown, it could potentially stir a new round of negotiations, and it signals Trumpís willingness to make some deal trading DACA protections for border security money.Trump also signaled that he has moved from his insistence of a 2,000-mile border wall along the entire U.S.-Mexico border to a more targeted approach. He referenced a ìsee-through steel barrier,î also known as a ìfence.î He spoke of border security in broader terms, like in increasing the number of border agents. And he offered those trades for immigration <U+2015> specifically, three years of legislative relief for DACA recipients, and three years of protections for refugees.The Trump administration†has attempted to shut down DACA, an Obama-era initiative that allowed around 700,000 young people, called Dreamers, to avoid deportation. It has also sought to severely restrict TPS, which allows people to reside in the U.S. if they come from certain nations undergoing conflict or recovering from a natural disaster. But both would get a three-year extension under Trumpís offer.That proposal is likely to anger Trumpís far-right base, however. Conservative author Ann Coulter <U+2015> whom Trump has taken policy cues from in the past <U+2015> tweeted that Trumpís offer was ì100 miles of border wall in exchange for amnestying millions of illegals.îìSo if we grant citizenship to a BILLION foreigners, maybe we can finally get a full border wall,î she said.Trump is also unlikely to move anyone on the left, but he and the White House are hoping thereís a strong group of independents who will see Trumpís effort to negotiate and begin blaming Democrats for the shutdown.Trump didnít spend time discussing the shutdown Saturday, but itís clear heís facing heat to get federal workers back to work. Polling suggests that 57 percent of Americans blame Trump for the shutdown, and his favorability has been slipping. But heís hoping he can at least convince some that heís working to find a solution <U+2015> even if his offer is one Democrats were able to easily reject.One thing Trump did intimate is that he still could use a national emergency declaration to get his border wall, or perhaps other statutes. Trump said he would get his border wall ìone way or the other.î That may offer Republicans and Democrats some hope, actually, as many on Capitol Hill believe the only way out of this shutdown is for Trump to declare a national emergency and try to redirect funds to a wall, have that move tied up in court, and then allow both parties to pass funding without giving in to the other side.The other option <U+2015> Republicans, Democrats and Trump actually working out a deal <U+2015> is both unlikely and unpalatable to many. But there are some lawmakers who think Trump could find a way out of the shutdown by making a grand deal on immigration.Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) has been†urging the president to offer the Democrats protections for immigrants to end the shutdown for weeks. And by offering support for the Bridge Act on Saturday <U+2015> legislation Graham co-sponsored <U+2015> the White House would allow DACA recipients to obtain three-year work permits and extend the TPS protections.†But in a sign of the long odds such a deal would face, Grahamís co-sponsor of the Bridge Act, Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), said in a statement that he could not support the presidentís offer and did not believe it could pass the Senate.Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) supported reopening the government and starting border security negotiations.ìBut if we reward this behavior it will never end, and the pain and chaos will be worse in the future,î he wrote over Twitter.†If we open up the government I am open to negotiations. But if we reward this behavior it will never end, and the pain and chaos will be worse in the future. Let this be the last shutdown. They always backfire.Referencing an Axios report that Jared Kushner and Vice President Mike Pence led negotiations with Republican members of Congress, Schatz said in a later tweet: ìYou donít negotiate a compromise with your own Vice President and your son in law. Thatís not how this works.îAnd Pelosi has said members of her party would not support any spending package that included funds for the wall that Trump envisions. In December, she said Democrats largely consider the massive infrastructure project ìimmoral, ineffective, expensive.î†ìNothing for the wall,î the speaker reiterated in a Jan. 2 interview with the ìTodayî showís Savannah Guthrie.Pelosi has also rejected the idea of exchanging border wall funding for DACA protections, saying in December that ìtheyíre two different subjects.îLate last year, Democratic congressional leaders offered $1.6 billion for border security, to be used for technological improvements and fencing, but not the 30-foot-high structure proposed by Trump.†The partial government shutdown has affected roughly 800,000 federal employees, who started to miss paychecks earlier this month. Many have shared their financial anxieties with news media, with some saying they have missed rent payments or are struggling to afford diapers.†Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? President Donald Trump seemed to discount reports of federal workers relying on food pantries or being unable to pay their mortgages during the ongoing partial government shutdown, saying Thursday that supermarket owners and home lenders would ìworkî with them during such difficult times.His comments came just hours after Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross shrugged off the woes of some 800,000 federal workers who have not been paid this year due to the shutdown, which has stretched into its second month.ìLocal people know who they are, when they go for groceries and everything else,î Trump said after being asked about Rossí statements. ìAnd I think what Wilbur was probably trying to say is that they will work along.îwhat pic.twitter.com/hBtyc7IqIDThe president noted that he hadnít heard Rossí comments himself and that ìperhaps he should have said it differently.î But Trump defended the man and said that banks were also ìworking alongî with those facing financial hardship during the shutdown, ìand thatís what happens in a time like this.îìIf you have mortgages, the mortgagees, the folks collecting the interest and all of those things, they work along,î Trump said.Ross has drawn fierce criticism for his remarks Thursday on CNBC that the media were forgetting people were ìeventually going to be paid.î He said he didnít ìreally quite understand whyî some people would have to rely on food banks. He also discounted the scope of those affected by the shutdown, alluding that the number of people only represented a fraction of the nationís financial output.ìPut it in perspective: Youíre talking about 800,000 workers, and while I feel sorry for individuals who have hardship cases, 800,000 workers, if they never got their pay, which is not the case, they will eventually get it, but if they never got it, youíre talking about a third of a percent on our GDP. So itís not like itís a gigantic number overall.îRoss, who also suggested that workers could simply take out loans to cover their expenses, is worth an estimated $700 million.The pairís comments fall in stark contrast to widespread reports of federal employees struggling to make ends meet. Workers are expected to miss their second paycheck of the year on Friday after Congress failed to pass any legislation meant to end the shutdown this week. An end to the impasse still appears to be far off.The commerce secretaryís statements drew swift rebukes from congressional Democrats, who accused Ross of espousing the ì21st century equivalent of ëLet them eat cake.íîìMany federal employees live paycheck to paycheck,î Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said Thursday on the Senate floor. ìSecretary Ross, they just canít call their stockbroker and ask them to sell some of their shares. ALBUQUERQUE, New Mexico ó With airline traffic stressed because of President Donald Trumpís government shutdown and another of his advisers indicted in the Russia investigation, his partyís chairwoman on Friday had this message: Everything is fine.ìThis president and his administration continue to do incredible things for our country,î†Republican National Committee†Chair Ronna McDaniel said at its winter meeting.†Republicans lost 40 seats and control of the House of Representatives last November and picked up just two seats in the Senate despite having the most favorable map in decades.McDaniel, however, spun the elections as a success for the party. ìWe minimized our losses in the House, in the face of a record 43 retirements,î she said ó but failed to mention that many of the retirements took place because Republican members felt they could not win because of Trumpís unpopularity.In her remarks, she did not mention Friday morningís indictment of former Trump campaign adviser Roger Stone, but did refer to what she called ìmanufactured scandals and baseless allegationsî against Trump.The indictment in the case, referred by special counsel Robert Muellerís office, states that Stone was in contact with a senior official of the Trump campaign in the final months of the 2016 presidential race regarding the release of stolen Hillary Clinton campaign emails. The U.S. intelligence community has stated that the emails were stolen by Russian spy agencies and passed along to WikiLeaks for release.Trump spent the final month of the campaign praising WikiLeaks at his rallies and telling his supporters to read the emails ó even though the Department of Homeland Security and the director of national intelligence on Oct. 7 stated that WikiLeaks was acting in concert with Russia.ìWe love WikiLeaks!î Trump said frequently.Shortly before her speech, McDaniel said she had not read or seen any news coverage about Stoneís indictment and could not comment on it. Many other RNC members gathered at the Hyatt Tamaya resort outside Albuquerque also said they did not know much about the indictment.ìI havenít read it yet,î said Ron Kaufman, a longtime RNC member from Massachusetts. ìI canít comment on something I havenít read.îThe RNC did, however, unanimously pass a resolution offering ìits undivided support for President Donald J. Trump and his effective presidency.îThe statement of support, though, does not mean the RNC is locked into backing Trump against any challengers in a primary, particularly if the Mueller investigation winds up causing legal troubles for Trump or his family, Ohio RNC member Jim Dicke said.ìActually these resolutions have no meaning,î he said, adding that it was done only because some members particularly supportive of Trump wanted to express that. ìWhat are the rest of us supposed to do? Say, ëNo, we donítí?îDicke also said that an indictment that draws a connection between Trumpís campaign and WikiLeaks was a significant development. ìThis is a big deal,î he said.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? This is where people are afraid to open up and say what's going on." pic.twitter.com/JSrRbnX47QPelosi,†who was elected House speaker this month after Democrats won control of the chamber, extended the traditional invitation to Trump†on Jan. 3 to deliver a State of the Union address before a joint session of Congress. WASHINGTON <U+2015>†Employees at the FBI, an institution still reeling from the attacks it has endured since the 2016 election, are dealing with another blow to morale as the government shutdown enters its second month.FBI special agents and employees, who will soon miss their second paychecks since the government shutdown began on Dec. 22, are scrambling to make ends meet. New FBI recruits just starting their careers through their training at Quantico, Virginia, have never received a paycheck.†The FBI SWAT team canít purchase critical gear. Some FBI employees are unable to put food on the table and are relying on food banks that FBI field offices have set up across the country.†A new report from the FBI Agents Association, an outside organization that advocates for bureau employees, lays out the effects of the partial government shutdown on the Federal Bureau of Investigation.†Thomas OíConnor, the president of the group, held a press conference on Tuesday to call attention to the shutdownís impact on FBI employees and the need to fund the bureau.ìWe are a motivated, professional, and patriotic lot, as you know, but we do have to make our bills like every other American ó red, blue, green, or otherwise,î one 22-year FBI veteran said in the report. ìNotwithstanding the obvious ... financial duress, there is also a very real impact on morale for us all.îìThe demoralization of employees is impacting operations because employees now have a significant point of stress distracting them as they perform their normal duties,î said another FBI employee.An agent whose wife is battling Stage 2 breast cancer is worried about being able to financially survive the shutdown and said he was ìangry at the unnecessary stress this shutdown is putting on my wife who just survived cancer and my 9-year-old son.îTwo FBI employees who recently bought their first home in a new city canít afford their mortgage. ìWe contacted our lender, and they are refusing to work with us,î the FBI employee said. ìThey donít want our ëHardship Letter,í they want money, period.îAnother employee of 24 years whose wife is battling terminal cancer said theyíve had to reach out for assistance from family and friends for the first time in his career.ìI am proud to be an Agent, proud to serve my country, and willing to sacrifice my life in defense of the people and the Constitution, but to have my family placed in the financial situation we are currently facing due to partisan politics is disgusting to me as a government employee and a citizen,î the agent said in the report.†While President Donald Trump has used the threat of MS-13 as justification for a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border, the shutdown has affected investigations into the gang, according to one FBI employee. The employee said the bureau had been working an investigation into MS-13 for three years and had indicted a number of members, but has not had a Spanish speaker in the division since the shutdown.ìWe have several Spanish speaking informants,î the employee said. ìWe are only able to communicate using a three-way call with a linguist in another division.îBureau employees are limited in what kind of outside jobs they can take, and already work long hours in often stressful jobs.†OíConnor credited FBI leadership with being flexible about the $3,000 cap on outside employment <U+2015> the FBIís shutdown Q&A page says ìflexibility is warrantedî with regard to the limit, given the unusual situation. But OíConnor said FBI special agents shouldnít have to be contemplating part-time work to being with.†ìFBI agents should not have to go work at a store stocking shelves because they canít feed their families on their government job,î OíConnor said. ìWhen are they going to find time to go get that second job?î†OíConnor also worried about the long-term impact on the bureauís ability to attract talent, given that new recruits at the FBI Academy at Quantico still havenít received their first paycheck from the government.ìThese people leave other jobs, many times taking a pay cut to join government service, they leave their families at home and they come to Quantico and they spend months at training. How long can you leave your family at home with your spouse and children, taking care of your family while youíre away doing your job and becoming an FBI agent, and you have no money to pay for mortgage, food, medical, anything that you need?î OíConnor asked. ìBrand new agents, at an entry level, are getting nothing and have gotten nothing.îAn FBI employee in the central region said in the report that an incoming FBI agent may move in with him and his wife to save money.†ìWe have a robust food bank going and hosted 200 federal employees for a free potluck lunch this week,î the FBI employee said. ìWe have a free breakfast planned for next week.î Another employee said that the ìdistraction of worrying about making ends meet is in the back of their minds.îìIíve always prided myself on being able to pay my bills on-time and in-full. The fact that I can no longer do that is humiliating and degrading,î said one FBI agent from the southeast region. ìLike many of my fellow agents, I took a sizable pay cut to come to serve my country as an FBI special agent. I accepted this position because I wanted to serve the cause of justice instead of clients. The idea that Iíd be forced to work without a paycheck or the ability to provide to my family was unthinkable to me when I made that decision to work here.îOíConnor said that he and his wife, who is also an agent, delivered an entire truckload of donated food to their office last night for an FBI employee in need. ìPhenomenal,î OíConnor said of the donations from citizens. ìAlso, I canít believe itís happening.îHuffPost readers: Are you affected by the government shutdown?†Email us about it. WASHINGTON <U+2015> The Senate is set to vote later this week on dueling measures that would reopen the government: one put forth by Republicans, the other by Democrats.Both proposals are almost certain to fall short of the necessary 60-vote threshold to advance, likely guaranteeing that the partial but costly government shutdown will continue for at least another week barring an unexpected breakthrough.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) on Tuesday announced an agreement with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) for a Thursday vote on a bill that includes $5.7 billion for President Donald Trumpís proposed wall on the southern border, as well as the temporary deportation relief Trump has proposed for some immigrants and refugees. The bill, which also calls for†major changes the would restrict asylum laws for Central American minors, is likely to get little or no Democratic support.†Under the McConnell-Schumer deal, the Senate will also vote Thursday on a House-passed bill that would provide funding to re-open all parts of the government until Feb. 8 while congressional leaders and Trump focus on trying to reach an accord on border security issues. This measure is unlikely to get enough Republican support because it does not include funding for Trumpís border wall, which as a candidate he promised Mexico would pay for.Only 10 GOP senators signed a bipartisan letter earlier this month calling on Trump to reopen the government with a similar short-term measure while negotiations over the border issues proceed. Thatís short of the 13 Republicans needed to advance the measure, assuming all 47 members of the Senate Democratic caucus support it. The GOPís Senate leadership actively lobbied members against signing the letter.The purpose of Thursdayís showdown may be more political than practical <U+2015> Anxious senators up for re-election in 2020 on both sides of the aisle would be able to tell constituents and federal workers they voted to re-open the government.†McConnell in a Tuesday floor speech urged Democrats to ìput country over partyî and ìtake yes for an answerî by accepting Trumpís offer, which the president announced over the weekend in a speech at the White House. McConnell called it the ìonly proposal currently before us that can be signed by the president and immediately re-open the government.îSchumer, meanwhile, slammed Trumpís proposal as ìone-sidedî and ìharshly partisan,î adding in his floor speech that no Democrats were involved in discussions over it. He called the proposed changes to asylum law in the bill a ìpoison pill,î and said the measure is ìgoing nowhere fast.îThe competing rhetoric that had little chance of resolving the shutdown that began on Dec. 22 occurred as some furloughed federal workers lined up at a food bank in downtown Washington, just blocks from the White House. Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.) compared that scene to†something out of the Great Depression.The furloughed federal workers just keep coming and coming to the World Central Kitchen. WASHINGTON <U+2015>†With President Donald Trump and the GOP prolonging the partial government shutdown, a Republican lawmaker had an uncomfortable run-in Tuesday when a fellow airplane passenger found him flying first class from Chicago to Washington, D.C., according to a video of the encounter shared with HuffPost.ìCongressman, do you think itís appropriate to fly first class while 57 TSA agents arenít being paid?î the person says to Rep. Rodney Davis (R-Ill.), in an apparent reference to the Transportation Security Administrationís 57,000 employees, who are being required to work without pay.†A tipster who asked to remain anonymous shared the video with HuffPost, which hasnít been able to identify the person who approached Davis.†Davis remained silent, prompting the person to say, ìTaking that as a yes.îìTaxpayers paid for this flight? Fair enough,î he added.Members of Congress can have the government pay for regular flights to and from their home jurisdictions, as maintaining constituency contact is part of their job. Unlike the paychecks of TSA workers, as well as those of hundreds of thousands of other federal government workers affected by the shutdown, those paid flights do not go away during a government shutdown.Davis did not use his taxpayer-provided budget to purchase a first-class ticket and has never done so, his spokeswoman Ashley Phelps told HuffPost in an email.His office bought a regular coach ticket, but he was upgraded automatically because of his frequent flyer status, she added. ìThere was no additional cost to taxpayers.îAccepting the upgrade is not a violation of anti-corruption rules because itís something available to any person who accrues a certain number of miles and wasnít offered exclusively to Davis because of his position as an elected representative, an ethics officer in the House, who asked to speak on background since the episode is not under any official investigation, told HuffPost.All the same,†for someone with power over peopleís paychecks to enjoy a luxe experience amid mass economic disruption makes for a jarring sight.A photograph of Davis in the first class section of the plane made it into Politicoís Playbook PM newsletter†on Tuesday.Most of the GOP has stood with President Donald Trump during the shutdown, arguing that heís right to reject deals to reopen the government until he gets the funding he wants for his promised wall on the border with Mexico.Davis has frequently supported the party on the issue, according to the Chicago Sun-Times, and praised Trumpís approach.†But the congressman recently sided with Democrats on bills to reopen some agencies <U+2015> a nod, perhaps, to his political vulnerability, given his tight re-election in the 2018 midterms.This story has been updated with comment from an ethics officer in the House.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? WASHINGTON (AP) ó President Donald Trump said heíll be making a ìmajor announcementî on the government shutdown and the southern border on Saturday afternoon as the standstill over his border wall continues into its fifth week.Democrats are proposing hundreds of millions of dollars for new immigration judges and improvements to ports of entry from Mexico but nothing for the wall, a House aide said, as the party begins fleshing out its vision of improving border security.After days of bitter clashes between Trump and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, it was unclear if the twin developments represented serious steps toward resolving the nasty partisan fight or posturing. But they were the first tangible signs of movement in a dispute that has caused a partial government shutdown, which Saturday entered its record 29th day.Trumpís refusal to sign spending bills that lack the $5.7 billion he wants to start constructing that wall, which Democrats oppose, has prompted the shutdown.The White House declined to provide details late Friday about what the president would be announcing. But Trump was not expected to sign the national emergency declaration heís been threatening as an option to circumvent Congress, according to two people familiar with the planning.Instead, Trump was expected to propose the outlines of a new deal that the administration believes could potentially pave the way to an end to the shutdown, according to one of the people. They were not authorized to discuss the announcement and spoke on condition of anonymity.The move, amid a shutdown that has left hundreds of thousands of federal workers without paychecks, represents the first major overture by the president since Jan. 8, when he delivered an Oval Office address making the public case for his border wall. Democrats have said they will not negotiate until the government reopens, raising questions about how Trump might move the ball forward.Democrats were proposing $563 million to hire 75 more immigration judges, who currently face large backlogs processing cases, and $524 million to improve ports of entry in Calexico, California, and San Luis, Arizona, the Democratic House aide said. The money is to be added to spending bills, largely negotiated between the House and Senate, that the House plans to vote on next week.In addition, Democrats were working toward adding money for more border security personnel and for sensors and other technology to a separate bill financing the Department of Homeland Security, but no money for a wall or other physical barriers, the aide said.It was possible Democrats would unveil that measure next week as the cornerstone of their border security alternative to Trumpís wall, the aide said.Earlier Friday, Rep. Lucille Roybal-Allard, D-Calif., who chairs the House Appropriations Committeeís homeland security subcommittee, said in an interview that some Democrats were asking leaders, ìWhat is our plan?ìThe aide spoke on condition of anonymity because he wasnít authorized to discuss the details publicly. The Democratsí spending plans were first reported by The New York Times.In a video posted on his Twitter feed late Friday, Trump said both sides should ìtake the politics out of itî and ìget to workî to ìmake a deal.î But he also repeated his warnings, saying: ìWe have to secure our southern border. If we donít do that, weíre a very, very sad and foolish lot.ìWhite House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders said only that Trump was ìgoing to continue fighting for border securityî and ìgoing to continue looking for the solutionî to end what the administration had repeatedly referred to as a ìhumanitarian and national security crisis at the border.ìWhile few would argue that a humanitarian crisis is unfolding at the U.S.-Mexico border, as the demand for entry by migrants and the Trump administrationís hardline response overwhelm border resources, critics say Trump has dramatically exaggerated the security risks and argue that a wall would do little to solve existing problems.Trump will be speaking from the Diplomatic Room at 3 p.m.Trumpís Friday evening tweeted announcement came after Pelosi (D-Calif.) on Friday canceled her plans to travel by commercial plane to visit U.S. troops in Afghanistan, saying Trump had caused a security risk by talking about the trip.The White House said there was no such leak.It was the latest turn ó and potentially the most dangerous ó in the high-stakes brinkmanship between Trump and Pelosi that has been playing out against the stalled negotiations over how to end the partial government shutdown.And it showed once again the willingness of the former hard-charging businessman to hit hard when challenged.It was an unusually combative week between the executive and legislative branches.Tensions flared when Pelosi suggested Trump postpone the annual State of the Union address, a grand Washington tradition ó and a platform for his border wall fight with Democrats ó that was tentatively scheduled for Jan. 29.Trump never responded directly. Instead, he abruptly canceled Pelosiís military flight on Thursday, hours before she and a congressional delegation were to depart for Afghanistan on the previously undisclosed visit to U.S. troops.Trump belittled the trip as a ìpublic relations eventî ó even though he had just made a similar stop in a conflict zone during the shutdown ó and said it would be best if Pelosi remained in Washington to negotiate to reopen the government.Pelosi, undeterred, quietly began making her own preparations for the overseas trip.But on Friday, Pelosi said her plan to travel by commercial plane had been ìleakedî by the White House.ìThe administration leaked that we were traveling commercially,î Pelosi told reporters at the Capitol. She said it was ìvery irresponsible on the part of the president.ìShe said the State Department told her ìthe president outingî the original trip made the scene on the ground in Afghanistan ìmore dangerous because itís a signal to the bad actors that weíre coming.ìThe White House said it had leaked nothing that would cause a security risk.Denying military aircraft to a senior lawmaker ó let alone the speaker, who is second in line to the presidency after the vice president, traveling to a combat region ó is very rare.Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff of California slammed Trump for revealing the closely held travel plan, calling it ìcompletely and utterly irresponsible in every way.ìSome Republicans expressed frustration. Sen. Lindsey Graham tweeted, ìOne sophomoric response does not deserve another.î He called Pelosiís State of the Union move ìvery irresponsible and blatantly politicalî but said Trumpís reaction was ìalso inappropriate.ì___Associated Press writers Deb Riechmann, Kevin Freking, Jon Lemire, Matthew Daly, Andy Taylor, Mary Clare Jalonick, Matt Lee, Lolita C. President Donald Trump said late Wednesday that he would postpone his State of the Union address until the partial government shutdown ends and that he was not looking for an alternative venue amid an ongoing stalemate with Democratic leaders.ìI will do the Address when the Shutdown is over,î the president said on Twitter, noting that he was ìnot looking for an alternative venue for the SOTU Address because there is no venue that can compete with the history, tradition and importance of the House Chamber.îAs the Shutdown was going on, Nancy Pelosi asked me to give the State of the Union Address. I agreed. She then changed her mind because of the Shutdown, suggesting a later date. This is her prerogative - I will do the Address when the Shutdown is over. I am not looking for an........alternative venue for the SOTU Address because there is no venue that can compete with the history, tradition and importance of the House Chamber. I look forward to giving a ìgreatî State of the Union Address in the near future!Trump quickly moved to shift blame for the delayed event to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.). She replied to the presidentís missives with a tweet of her own shortly before midnight, saying she hoped ìby saying ënear futureí you mean you will support the House-passed package to #EndTheShutdown that the Senate will vote on tomorrow.îìPlease accept this proposal so we can re-open government, repay our federal workers and then negotiate our differences,î she concluded.Pelosi had†initially requested the president delay the address amid the ongoing shutdown, which has stretched into its second month. About 800,000 federal workers have been affected and are set to miss their second paychecks of the year on Friday.The president later fired back at the suggestion, saying he would give his address as planned on Jan. 29. The GOP proposal would give Trump the $5.7 billion heís demanded for a wall along the southern border, while the other plan would reopen the government through Feb. 8 without a wall but allow for negotiations to continue while federal employees get back to work.Neither proposal is expected to get the 60 votes needed to advance, meaning the shutdown will likely drag on for at least another week.Trump has continued to heap criticism on Democrats, telling reporters this week that the party had ìbecome radicalized.î However, House Democrats said theyíd be willing to up the budget for border security, possibly to the $5.7 billion level requested by the president, if the government could be reopened and those funds be used for measures other than a barrier.This article has been updated to include a response from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? A herd of elephant seals that moved onto a California beach during Januaryís government shutdown shows no sign of giving up its newly gained territory in the immediate future.ìAs you may have heard, Drakes Beach is under new management,î Point Reyes National Seashore†wrote on Facebook†on Friday afternoon. ìElephant seals have taken over!!!îThe post said that while the beach would remain closed to humans this weekend ìat the direction of the new management,î the nearby road and parking lot would be open during the day for elephant seal viewing.Earlier this week, SFGate reported that around 50 to 60 adult elephant seals had made themselves comfortable on the beach and around 35 pups had been born. The seals also plowed through a fence to spill out into the adjacent parking area.They did this all while wildlife management staffers were furloughed because of the government shutdown.John DellíOsso, chief of interpretation and resource education at Point Reyes National Seashore,†told Vice that if the shutdown hadnít been underway, staffers would have been around to discourage the seals from congregating in the area, likely using tarps and waving at them to move off.But now that pups have arrived, itís best for the seals that they be allowed to stay, at least for a while.ìTheyíre at a critical time: the pups have been born there, theyíre nursing,î DellíOsso told The Guardian. ìWeíre not going to disrupt that process.îThe seals wonít remain on the beach forever, though.†ìPups usually wean from their mothers in late March - early April,î DellíOsso told HuffPost in an email. ìSo our best guess is by sometime in April, most of the elephant seals will disperse.îThis story has been updated with an additional comment from John DellíOsso.

Earlier this month, the partial government shutdown caused the Food and Drug Administration to postpone its inspection of various foods, leaving many Americans wondering if their safety is at risk.Hereís the lowdown at this current moment.The U.S. Department of Agriculture, which monitors the countryís meat and poultry slaughterhouses, has reported that 90 percent of its workforce remains on the job.The FDA, which is responsible for flagging food safety issues on all other foods (you may remember the recent romaine recall), resumed many of its inspections on Jan. 15. FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb, who shares regular updates on Twitter, said that furloughed workers were being recalled to do their jobs unpaid.On Jan. 16, Gottlieb tweeted an update, saying a bill had been signed into law that would ìguarantee that federal workers who are furloughed or working without pay will be compensated for the period of funding lapse.îMost of the foods affected by the inspection delays are low-risk foods that arenít typically the cause of foodborne illnesses. Instead, FDA workers have been conducting regular inspections on ìhigh riskî foods, which make up about 31 percent of the agencyís workload. Hereís the list of foods that are still being inspected:Modified atmosphere packaged products; acidified and low acid canned foods; seafood; custard filled bakery products; dairy products including soft, semi-soft, soft ripened cheese and cheese products, unpasteurized juices; sprouts ready-to-eat; fresh fruits and vegetables and processed fruits and vegetables; spices; shell eggs; sandwiches; prepared salads; infant formula; and medical foods.The FDA defines a foodborne illness, of which there are 48 million cases a year in the U.S., as a reaction to consuming food contaminated with pathogens, chemicals or toxins. Essentially, foods deemed to be at highest risk of carrying foodborne illnesses are still being regularly inspected. This could change, however, so itís important to check Gottliebís Twitter account, which posts frequent updates.Regardless of the FDAís rate of food inspections, itís always a good idea to practice the agencyís food safety guidelines when cooking at home. Follow the guidelines in the infographics below for best practices.HuffPost readers: Are you affected by the government shutdown? Email us about it. WASHINGTON <U+2015> Two dueling proposals to reopen parts of the federal government failed to advance in the Senate on Thursday, signaling that the partial but costly government shutdown likely will continue for at least another week.A bill put forth by Republicans including $5.7 billion for President Donald Trumpís proposed wall on the southwestern border, as well as temporary deportation relief for some immigrants and refugees, was blocked by a vote of 50 to 47.†A Democratic bill that would have provided funding to reopen all parts of the government until Feb. 8 while congressional leaders and Trump focus on trying to reach an accord on border security issues also failed to pass,†52 to 44. Six Republicans bucked the president and voted for the measure: Lamar Alexander (Tenn.), Susan Collins (Maine), Cory Gardner (Colo.), Johnny Isakson (Ga.), Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) and Mitt Romney (Utah).†Both measures fell short of the 60-vote threshold to advance.Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), the only Democrat who supported both proposals, said he did so because they represented ìa start to finding a way to reopenî the government.Roughly a quarter of the government has been shut down since Dec. 22, after Trump refused to sign any appropriations bill that didnít include funding for the border wall. The consequences of the showdown have been mounting for 800,000 federal workers forced off the job, with many struggling to pay rent and other bills after missing paychecks.A top Trump adviser warned this week that the economy may show no growth in the first quarter if the shutdown lasts much longer.†Democrats say they oppose building the wall ó which Trump as a candidate promised Mexico would pay for ó because it would be an ineffective deterrent against unauthorized immigration. They also argue that giving in to the president now would simply legitimize the tactic of shutting down the government over policy disagreements in future budget fights.Republicans, meanwhile, say additional barriers on the border are common-sense and needed. They also point out that congressional Democrats have agreed many times to fund construction of barriers on the border <U+2015> under Republican and Democratic administrations.†Itís unclear what, if anything, Thursdayís votes accomplished.Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) met with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) in his office Thursday afternoon to discuss a way forward that involves reopening the government for three weeks while both sides continue talking over border security. The 30-minute discussion between two leaders followed weeks of competing rhetoric on the Senate floor, leading some observers to believe that a breakthrough on the shutdown was near.But the idea quickly ran into opposition from the White House, which insisted in a statement on Thursday that any short-term measure reopening the government include a ìlarge down paymentî on the wall.Senate Democrats, meanwhile, said they could not support the idea of giving Trump funds for his border wall unless he reopens the government first.ìWhat does he hold workersí wages hostage for next? How many times will he try to hold wages hostage?î Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.) told reporters on Thursday.Meanwhile, Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) havenít spoken in weeks <U+2015> save for a sharp exchange of letters about†postponing the presidentís annual State of the Union address because of the shutdown.Pelosi on Thursday similarly shot down the latest White House proposal to fund the wall.ìThat is not a reasonable agreement between senators,î Pelosi said on the House floor.†A group of House Democrats are working on a package that would meet Trumpís request of $5.7 billion†but only for border security measures other than a wall, such as technology, more agents and measures intended to fortify ports of entry. Itís unclear if he would accept such a proposal, but the legislation would allow some anxious Democrats to say they are negotiating with the president in good faith and trying to reopen the government.This story has been updated throughout.Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?
